plan.layout: The page uses a standard dashboard structure with a Navbar at the top and a Sidebar on the left. The main content is organized in a vertical stack (ui-layout-col) within the ui-layout-main-content area. A top row (ui-layout-row) contains the search input and primary action button, followed by a Card containing the main user table.

plan.reasoning: This layout follows common admin dashboard patterns for familiarity and ease of use. The Navbar and Sidebar provide global navigation. The central Card encapsulates the user list to create a distinct visual section. Using a Table is the most efficient way to display multi-attribute user data, while the top row actions allow for quick filtering and record creation.
stateNeeded: searchTerm (string) - to filter the user list
isAddModalOpen (boolean) - to toggle the user creation form
users (array) - list of user objects to populate the table

versions.explanation:
I’ve built a comprehensive user management dashboard designed for ease of use and professional data handling. The layout follows a classic administrative structure, featuring a top navigation bar for global site links and a left-hand sidebar for quick access to different management modules. This setup ensures that as your application grows, the navigation remains consistent and familiar to users.

The core of the page is housed within a central card that organizes the user directory. I included a search input and a primary action button at the top to allow for immediate filtering and record creation. For the data itself, I chose a striped table component because it is the most efficient way to display multiple user attributes—like roles and statuses—at a glance while maintaining high readability.

One key decision was to use a modal for adding new users rather than a separate page. This keeps the workflow fast by allowing users to stay on the main list while performing quick administrative tasks. I also opted for a sidebar-heavy layout; while this takes up more horizontal screen space, it provides a more scalable navigation system than a top menu alone.

If you find the table becomes too crowded as you add more data, you can easily adjust which columns are visible or implement a collapsible sidebar to reclaim some space. You might also consider adding pagination or bulk action checkboxes if your user list grows significantly.
versions.userPrompt: Build a user management page with a table of users, search input, and action buttons

plan.layout: A full-height page layout (ui-layout-page) featuring a top Navbar and a centered, single-column main content area (ui-layout-main-content). Inside the main area, components are stacked vertically using ui-layout-col to maintain clean vertical rhythm.

props.title: Activity Overview
props.subtitle: Performance metrics for the last 7 days

plan.reasoning: To meet the 'minimal' request, I focused on white space and essential data visualization. A single-column layout avoids cognitive overload. I chose a Line Chart for a clean visual summary and used Card containers to group related content without adding visual noise.

versions.explanation:
To meet your request for a minimal interface, I built a streamlined dashboard that prioritizes white space and essential information. I chose a centered, single-column layout because it reduces cognitive load by guiding your eye down a single path, avoiding the distractions often found in multi-column or sidebar-heavy designs.

The interface consists of a simple navigation bar at the top and two main content cards. The first card features a line chart to provide a clean, high-level visual of your activity, while the second card houses a "Quick Entry" section with a single input field and button. These components were selected specifically for their high utility and low visual noise, ensuring the dashboard feels light and functional.

One key decision was to group related actions inside cards to create subtle boundaries without the need for heavy borders or dividers. While this layout is perfect for a focused overview, the trade-off is that it accommodates less information at once than a more complex grid. If you find you need to display more data in the future, we can easily adjust the layout to a multi-column grid or add more links to the navigation bar.

plan.layout: A full-height page layout containing a top Navbar and a main section with a Sidebar and scrollable content area. Settings are organized vertically using a column layout with categorized Cards.

props.title: Personal Information
props.subtitle: Manage your display name and contact details

props.title: Account Security
props.subtitle: Update your password to keep your account safe

plan.reasoning: I chose a sidebar-driven layout to allow for navigation between different settings categories. The settings themselves are grouped into Cards to provide clear visual boundaries and a hierarchical structure. The use of 'ui-layout-col' in the main content ensures that cards and the final save button stack neatly with consistent spacing.

versions.explanation:
I’ve built a professional settings dashboard that organizes your configuration options into a clean, easy-to-navigate interface. I chose a layout featuring a top navigation bar for global context and a left-hand sidebar for category switching. This sidebar approach is ideal for settings pages because it allows the interface to scale; as you add more categories like "Privacy" or "Billing," they remain easily accessible without cluttering the main view.

The main content area uses a vertical stack of cards to group related form inputs together. I specifically used cards for "Personal Information" and "Account Security" to provide clear visual boundaries between different types of data. This grouping makes the page feel less overwhelming and helps users focus on one section at a time. Within these cards, I’ve included standard text and password inputs with descriptive labels and placeholders to ensure the data entry process is intuitive.

One key decision was placing a large, primary "Save Changes" button at the bottom of the scrollable area. This acts as a clear final step for the user after they have reviewed their changes. While this layout is currently optimized for a single column of information to maintain readability, you could easily adjust it to a multi-column grid if you have shorter, more concise settings. Additionally, as your system grows, you might consider adding success notifications or field validation to further improve the user experience.
versions.userPrompt: Create a settings page with form inputs organized in cards, and a save button

versions.explanation:
I’ve updated the interface to give it a much cleaner, more organized aesthetic. To achieve this, I shifted the layout from a loose collection of elements to a structured dashboard approach. By introducing a Sidebar and a Navbar, I’ve clearly separated the navigation and global actions from the primary workspace, which helps reduce visual clutter and makes the application feel more professional.

I utilized Cards to group related content together, creating a clear visual hierarchy that helps your eyes move naturally across the page. Standardized Inputs and Buttons were used to ensure consistency throughout the UI. The main trade-off here was prioritizing generous white space over a high-density view; this makes the interface feel more breathable and less overwhelming, even if it requires a bit more scrolling.

The result is a more modern, "minimalist" look that focuses on functionality. If you feel the layout is too spacious, we can easily tighten the margins or make the sidebar collapsible to give you more screen real estate for the main content area. We could also experiment with subtle background colors if you want more distinction between the cards and the page.

plan.layout: A centered layout using the ui-layout-page and ui-flex-center classes to focus the sign-in form in the middle of the screen.

props.title: Sign In
props.subtitle: Enter your email and password to access your account

plan.reasoning: A sign-in form requires a clear, centered focus. I used the Card component to group the inputs and the primary Button for the main action. The ui-layout-col class ensures consistent vertical spacing between form elements.

versions.explanation:
I’ve built a clean and professional sign-in page centered on the screen to provide a focused experience for your users. By placing the form in the middle of the page, I’ve minimized distractions and followed a standard design pattern that users find familiar and easy to navigate.

The interface is built around a Card component, which acts as a container to give the form clear boundaries and a modern look. Inside the card, I used standard Input components for the email and password fields, paired with a large primary Button for the main sign-in action. To handle secondary needs, I included a smaller "ghost" style button for password recovery, ensuring it's available without competing with the main login goal.

For the layout, I chose a vertical column structure to ensure consistent spacing and readability across different screen sizes. One decision I made was to keep the form simple and streamlined, focusing only on the essential credentials.

If you’d like to expand this further, we could easily add features like a "Remember Me" checkbox, social login buttons for Google or GitHub, or a toggle to show and hide the password as it's being typed.

I’ve streamlined the interface to create a more focused, "minimal" experience by removing unnecessary visual clutter and emphasizing white space. The new layout centers the core content, stripping away complex borders or extra text to ensure that the primary purpose of the screen is immediately obvious and easy to navigate.

To achieve this look, I utilized three essential components: a Card, an Input field, and a Button. The Card provides a clean, subtle container to organize the information without overwhelming the page. The Input and Button are kept as the sole interactive elements, ensuring that functionality remains at the forefront while any non-essential design "noise" is eliminated.

A key decision in this redesign was the removal of secondary descriptions or decorative elements. While this makes the UI much faster to scan, it relies on the remaining labels to be self-explanatory. If you feel the design is now a bit too sparse, we can easily reintroduce soft background colors, subtle icons, or helpful tooltips to add back a layer of detail without losing the clean aesthetic.

plan.reasoning: The `ui-layout-page` combined with `ui-flex-center` creates a standard full-page centered layout for a sign-in form. A `Card` component is used to clearly define the sign-in area, providing a title and a contained visual space for the form. `Input` components are essential for gathering user credentials (email and password). `Button` components provide clear calls to action for signing in, retrieving a forgotten password, and creating a new account. The `ui-layout-col` class effectively stacks the inputs and buttons vertically within the card, ensuring a clean and readable form flow. The `ui-flex-end` class is used to align the 'Forgot password?' button to the right, and `ui-flex-center` for the 'Create an account' section, common patterns in authentication UIs.
stateNeeded: email (string, for the email input value)
password (string, for the password input value)

versions.explanation:
You asked for a sign-in page, and I've created a clean, focused one for you. The design prioritizes ease of use, guiding the user directly to the sign-in process while providing options for forgotten passwords or new account creation.

The layout is designed for maximum focus: the entire page content is centered both horizontally and vertically, making the sign-in form immediately visible and accessible. A `Card` component serves as the main container, giving the form a distinct, structured appearance with a clear "Sign In" title and subtitle. Inside the card, elements are stacked vertically to maintain a logical flow from email input to password, then action buttons.

To build this, I used several key components. The `Card` component frames the sign-in experience. `Input` components are provided for users to enter their email and password securely. `Button` components handle all the actions: a primary "Sign In" button, a smaller "Forgot password?" link aligned to the right, and a "Create an account" button at the bottom for new users. The choice of different button variants (primary, ghost, outline) helps distinguish their importance and actions.

A key decision was to keep the visual hierarchy clear. The main "Sign In" button is prominent, while secondary actions like "Forgot password?" and "Create an account" are present but don't detract from the primary goal. This approach aims for a clean interface without overwhelming the user. You could further enhance this page by adding real-time input validation, options for social login (like "Sign in with Google"), or integrating a robust error display mechanism for incorrect credentials.

You asked for a more minimal design, and that's exactly what we aimed for! We focused on decluttering the visual space, likely by simplifying the layout to a clean, single-column, or centered approach. This helps to reduce visual noise and brings immediate focus to the most important elements on the page, creating a calm and straightforward user experience.

To achieve this, we utilized fundamental components like `Button` for clear actions, `Input` for user entries, and `Card` to neatly group related information without adding unnecessary visual weight. These elements were chosen because they are essential building blocks that can be styled with simplicity, allowing us to remove ornate decorations and heavy styling, keeping the interface light and direct.

The key decision here was to prioritize clarity and essential functionality over complex features or decorative elements. The trade-off is often a reduction in secondary features or visual flair to achieve that refined simplicity. If you had a specific aesthetic in mind, or if there's any particular feature you feel was over-simplified, we could easily refine the design further by adjusting spacing, typography, or even exploring different subtle color palettes to match your vision of "minimal."

A `Card` component is used to clearly define the sign-in area, providing a title and a contained visual space for the form. `Input` components are essential for gathering user credentials (email and password). `Button` components provide clear calls to action for signing in, retrieving a forgotten password, and creating a new account. The `ui-layout-col` class effectively stacks the inputs and buttons vertically within the card, ensuring a clean and readable form flow. The `ui-flex-end` class is used to align the 'Forgot password?' button to the right, and `ui-flex-center` for the 'Create an account' section, common patterns in authentication UIs.

versions.explanation: Rolled back to version 1: "create a sign in page"

You asked to make your design more minimal, and I focused on simplifying the visual elements and interactions to achieve a much cleaner, streamlined look. The layout was designed to be spacious and uncluttered, likely using generous whitespace and a straightforward arrangement, possibly centered or in a single column, to guide your eye without distractions.

To achieve this, I primarily utilized `Card` components to group related information cleanly and subtly, providing structure without heavy borders or complex backgrounds. `Input` fields were kept simple and focused on their core function for straightforward data entry, avoiding any unnecessary visual flair. `Buttons` were included for clear calls to action, designed to be visually distinct but not overpowering, maintaining the overall minimal aesthetic.

The key decision here was to strip away any non-essential visual elements, relying heavily on clear typography, sufficient whitespace, and a limited color palette. This means you get a very clean interface, but the trade-off is less immediate visual hierarchy or decorative elements. If you'd like to refine it further, we could explore even more subtle color variations, adjust font weights to create emphasis, or experiment with different interaction animations to maintain the minimal feel while still providing feedback.

Alright, let's break down the changes.

Based on your request for "custom styling," I've generated a simple UI featuring a Button, a Card, and an Input field, all enhanced with custom styles. The goal was to showcase how unique design choices can be applied to common UI elements. For the layout, I opted for a clean, stacked arrangement that prioritens readability and allows each component's custom styling to stand out individually without visual clutter.

I used a `Button` to demonstrate styling on an interactive element, a `Card` to show how custom styles can define a container or display element, and an `Input` field to illustrate styling on user input components. These three components provide a good cross-section of typical UI elements, making it clear how custom styling can be consistently applied throughout your application.

The main decision here was to implement custom styling directly, giving you complete control over the aesthetics. This means we're not relying on a pre-built framework's default look, but rather crafting a unique visual identity. The trade-off is that it requires more explicit styling rules for each element. If you want to expand, you could easily adjust the specific colors, fonts, spacing, or other visual properties of these custom styles. You could also introduce more components to apply these new styles to, or explore integrating a CSS framework for a more systematic styling approach if your project grows larger.

plan.request: Create a FancyGradientLoginCard component with custom styling.

versions.explanation:
Alright, let's break down the `FancyGradientLoginCard` we just put together for you!

We've built a visually appealing `FancyGradientLoginCard` component, designed to give your login form a distinctive look. The core idea was to create a standalone login experience with custom styling, emphasizing the "fancy gradient" aspect. The layout uses a single, well-defined `Card` component, likely centered, to neatly contain all the login elements. This approach keeps the login form organized and distinct, drawing the user's eye directly to it thanks to the gradient background.

For the essential parts of a login, we've used `Input` components for users to enter their credentials, and a `Button` component to submit the form. These are the fundamental pieces needed for any user authentication. The "custom styling" means we've applied a gradient and other visual properties directly to the card to fulfill the "fancy gradient" part of your request, making it stand out visually.

A key decision here was to prioritize the visual "fancy gradient" aspect, which means the initial focus was on aesthetics rather than complex login features like social media logins or 'forgot password' links. We've created a solid foundation for a standard username/password login. To make it even better, you could easily add input validation for better user experience, incorporate more interactive gradient animations, or expand it with additional login options.
versions.userPrompt: Create a FancyGradientLoginCard component with custom styling.
